rsbNotes.title: Luke 18:18
rsbNotes.text:
18:18 ruler. A general term meaning someone from the upper classes.

Good Teacher. This was not a usual form of address in Judaism; it was mere flattery. The man assumed that his deeds would bring him to eternal life.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 18:19
rsbNotes.text: 18:19 Why do you call me good. Jesus challenges the ruler’s flattery by reminding him that true goodness is an attribute of God alone. That his flattery was indeed insincere is shown by his failure to do what the “Good Teacher” taught him (v. 23).

rsbNotes.title: Luke 18:22
rsbNotes.text: 18:22 Sell all. This challenge revealed that the young man had not really understood the commandments. When he was faced with the choice, it became clear that his possessions came before God.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 18:23–25
rsbNotes.text: 18:23–25 See note Mark 10:25. The wealthy are tempted to rely on earthly things, together with those whose wealth is achievement in intellectual, artistic, or other fields. Great achievers often find it difficult to rely wholly on the mercy of God.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 18:26–27
rsbNotes.text: 18:26, 27 If the rich with all their advantages cannot easily be saved, who can be? The answer is that salvation, for rich or poor, is always the gift of God.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 18:28–30
rsbNotes.text: 18:28–30 Jesus’ answer to Peter means that God’s gifts surpass anything we can give up for Him. It does not mean that we can make sacrifices as a means of getting a better reward.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 18:31–34
rsbNotes.text: 18:31–34 In His predictions of the Passion (cf. 5:35; 9:22, 43–45; 12:50; 13:32, 33; 17:25), this is the first time Jesus speaks of being handed over to the Gentiles.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 18:35
rsbNotes.text:
18:35 draw near to Jericho. Luke implies Jesus was entering Jericho, whereas Matthew and Mark say the incident occurred as they “went out” of Jericho (Matt. 20:30; Mark 10:46). There seem to have been two “Jerichos” about a mile apart: the ruins of the Old Testament city conquered by Joshua (Josh. 6), and a city built by Herod the Great. The encounter may have happened as Jesus was leaving the old city and entering the new.

a blind man. Matthew mentions two blind men (cf. Matt. 9:27 and note), while Luke and Mark mention only one (named Bartimaeus, Mark 10:46); he may have been the spokesman for the two.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 18:38
rsbNotes.text: 18:38 Son of David. A messianic title.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 18:42
rsbNotes.text:
18:42 your faith. Faith was the means by which the gift was received.

has made you well. This might be translated “has saved you,” which would fit in with his following Jesus and praising God.
